skill.name: commit-message
skill.description: Format git commit messages combining Conventional Commits summary lines with Linux kernel-style bodies. Use when writing, reviewing, or formatting commit messages.
skill.summary: Format git commit messages combining Conventional Commits summary lines with Linux kernel-style bodi...
skill.author: Chemiseblanc

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based documentation skill containing only markdown formatting guidelines. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, and no command execution capabilities. Pure documentation for commit message conventions.

content.user_title: Format commit messages with proven conventions
content.value_statement: Poorly formatted commit messages make history hard to read and automate. This skill applies Conventional Commits for summary lines and Linux kernel style for body text, creating clear and searchable commit history.
actual_capabilities: Generate Conventional Commits summary lines with type, scope, and description
Write Linux kernel-style body text with proper line wrapping
Format breaking changes with proper notation
Create consistent, searchable commit messages from prompts
limitations: Does not execute git commands or modify repositories
Does not validate against actual commit history
Does not integrate with git hooks or CI/CD
Does not generate release notes automatically

use_cases.title: Maintain clean git history
use_cases.description: Generate well-formatted commits that work with automated changelog tools and semantic versioning

use_cases.title: Review commit messages
use_cases.description: Check if proposed commits follow established conventions before merging

use_cases.title: Match project standards
use_cases.description: Create commits that match contribution guidelines for Linux kernel and similar projects

prompt_templates.title: Simple commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Conventional Commits message for fixing the null pointer exception in user authentication

prompt_templates.title: Feature with body
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a commit message for adding dark mode support to the settings page. Include the reason why this improves user experience

prompt_templates.title: Breaking change
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a breaking change commit for removing the deprecated /v1/users endpoint from the API

prompt_templates.title: Refactoring work
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a refactor commit message for extracting database connection logic into a separate service module

output_examples.input: Create a commit message for fixing the memory leak in the image processing module
output: fix(images): resolve memory leak in buffer deallocation
The image processing module held references to processed buffers
preventing garbage collection. Moving to explicit cleanup after
rendering reduces memory usage by 40% for batch operations.
Users processing large batches of images will see reduced memory

best_practices: Keep summary lines under 50 characters for readability in git logs
Explain the 'why' in body text, not the 'what' (code shows what changed)
Use imperative mood consistently in both summary and body
anti_patterns: Using past tense in commit messages ('Added feature' instead of 'Add feature')
Leaving trailers like Signed-off-by in the commit body
Exceeding 72 characters per line in the body

faq.question: What Conventional Commits types are supported?
faq.answer: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, perf, test, build, ci, and chore. Each has a specific purpose in semantic versioning.

faq.question: What is the hard character limit for summary lines?
faq.answer: The hard limit is 72 characters. Keep summaries under 50 characters when possible for better git log readability.

faq.question: How does this integrate with git hooks?
faq.answer: This skill generates message text only. You would copy the output into your commit editor or use git commit -m with the generated message.

faq.question: Is my repository data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a pure prompt skill that generates text. It never reads or writes to your repository.

faq.question: Why should I use Linux kernel style for the body?
faq.answer: Linux kernel style wraps text at 72 columns, making messages readable in terminal git logs and preserving context in plain text viewers.

faq.question: How does this compare to commitlint?
faq.answer: This skill helps craft messages. Commitlint validates existing messages. Use both together: craft with this skill, validate with commitlint.
